title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: EPA employees accuse Trump officials of undermining the agency’s mission
items.description: “Declaration of Dissent” denounces partisan messaging, rollback of environmental regulations, and dismantling of science office, among other concerns

items.title: Scientists identify culprit behind biggest-ever U.S. honey bee die-off
items.description: USDA research points to viruses spread by pesticide-resistant mites, indicating a worrying trend

items.title: Scattershot vaccination fails to slow mpox spread in Congo
items.description: Limited vaccine doses weren’t used strategically, WHO analysis finds

items.title: How do research careers compare across countries? New global database has some answers
items.description: Online tool from the Research and Innovation Careers Observatory allows users to compare salary, typical career destinations, and more

items.title: Trump cuts subscriptions to Springer Nature journals
items.description: Other publishers appear unscathed in recent actions

items.title: WHO panel favors natural origin of COVID-19 virus but decries missing evidence
items.description: New report doesn’t rule out that SARS-CoV-2 leaked from a lab in China, but says evidence for scenario remains “speculation”

items.title: Social media attacks on public health agencies are eroding trust
items.description: Attacks on an institution’s integrity spur more anger—and engagement—than other types of criticisms, study suggests

items.title: UV-C light kills nearly everything—except this unusual organism
items.description: Built-in Sun protection might be a blueprint for surviving in space

items.title: China’s massive coastal restoration project could backfire
items.description: Study finds that efforts to replace an invasive weed could spike greenhouse gas emissions in the region

items.title: The U.S. reneged on aid commitments. Nepal’s malnourished children are paying the price
items.description: Hard-won progress in improving child and maternal nutrition hangs in the balance
